Comment: WASHINGTON – "Hillary Rodham Clinton yesterday brought up the assassination of Robert F. Kennedy while defending her decision to stay in the race against Barack Obama – drawing a furious reaction from the front-runner’s camp.

“My husband did not wrap up the nomination in 1992 until he won the California primary somewhere in the middle of June, right? We all remember Bobby Kennedy was assassinated in June in California. I don’t understand it,” she said, dismissing calls to drop out.

Obama campaign spokesman Bill Burton rebuked Clinton, saying her remark was “unfortunate and has no place in this campaign.”

Any comments about assassination and the primary contest are especially sensitive because Obama is the first African-American to advance so far in the race for the White House and he has faced threats, congressional sources have said.

Clinton later apologized (or, more precisely, expressed “regret” that people had taken offense)."

New York Post May 24, 2008

Comment: You have misled to a shocking degree.  The 500  million in Medicare and Title X (family planning) funds is 40% of Planned Parenthood budget, the remainder is private funding.  Only 3% of total PP funding is used for abortions; the rest is for women's health care, family planning education (which decreases pregnancies thereby preventing abortions) and contraception, which also decreases abortions.  Overall, Planned Parenthood probably prevents as many abortions as it provides.  Taxpayers, state and federal, subsidize or wholly pay for 24% of all abortion costs.   http://www.forbes.com/sites/theapothecary/2015/10/02/are-american-taxpayers-paying-for-abortion/#31b12a627709

The Hyde Amendment prohibits federal spending for most abortions.  But if we apply the Forbes 24% to PP, then 24% of 3% of 40%, or 0.29% of PP funds go to abortion.  So of PP's 1.3 billion budget,  3.77 million taxpayer dollars, state and federal, go to abortions.  That's 11 dollars and 78 cents per abortion,

Comment: When three-and-a-half in 1900 or three ping-pong balls in 1800 (courtesy of Mark Shore) have virtually no effect.....then you can rest assured that we're not dealing with a "poisonous" molecule. Don't get me wrong - the climate IS warming, bit by bit since we left the last ice age. That's called Climate Change......and yes, we should be taking some common sense actions to mitigate its effects.......but hitching your wagons to nothing other than CO2 is simply denial that there are other, more meaningful forces at work. I suspect that with the IPCC adjusting and "smoothing" the historical temperature record, you've lost track of the cyclical nature of Mother Nature's thermostat - it goes down and then up, down and up.......but always working itself towards being a wee bit warmer. Are we contributing? Yep, you bet. How much? That's the debate - but only for those with an open mind.

Comment: The Lake Oswego school district is supported by a special levy for operating funding outside the State revenue sharing.  The citizen led campaign is based on the premise that the value of property there is very much impacted by the quality of the schools.  You can buy an equal home in Beaverton,  for example,  for $200,000 or more LESS money.  And get schools that do not measure up to the expectations and demands of LO Schools.  So people pay the big money to have a home in the LO school district because the quality of the schools,  and the limited inventory of homes,  drive the supply down,  the demand up.  Hence the value.  So people buy into that,  and pay a surcharge on property taxes,  which are already high due to high appraisals,  to have the schools they want.  In the meantime,  the school equalization formula means that many, many of those people are paying their property taxes into the pot,  and LO Schools don't get back what residents put in,  but poorer districts do get.

Comment: Been using siped tires exclusively for 45 years---nothing better, including studs, for anything approaching normal miles and speeds---my chains have been on the ground only 3 times in all those years and in many vehicles including many commercial combinations. 

Studs should be banned and recycled forthwith---don't even keep them to wear them out---if you observe closely the wear on your tires then you will see that the new stud protrudes significantly but after only a couple hundred miles on dry pavement the stud length is much closer to the tread and of much less use even on ice. 

Siped tires handle water so much better and run cooler which means there is less micro-melting at the tread anyway. And with thousands of "edges" for contact to the surface instead of the hundred or so of studs, they are superior in all ways anyway. It is true that a studded tire will perform the same with any ham handed driving they encounter but for those who are smooth and thoughtful, siped tires shine.

Comment: EFC, Thank you for your reply.

I understand that there is room here for people of good will to see the situation differently. However, I do think saying that prosecution is not recommended falls under the finding that no criminal act occurred. If I understand Comey correctly, it seems he and his panel did not find that there was any intent involved and, for them, that is what separates it from a criminal act. Apparently he sees a distinction between "extreme negligence" and "gross negligence" that many others do not.  

The issue is that, not just Comey, but the FBI panel that reviewed the issue unanimously agreed that it did not meet the definition you have quoted. So, the question you are asking should go to him and the panel that reviewed the situation (reopening the investigation may be that they are having second thoughts).  

I understand the seriousness of this issue. I also understand that how one sees it will, very likely, fall under partisan lines. 

Respectfully,
John David

Comment: "...fear is a personal issue, and it's not up to Parliament to censure it or decide on means to "quell" it."

Ignorance is a personal issue too. People have the right to remain in fear and ignorance both. But as a society we constantly seek ways to lessen ignorance.We do it both for the individual's and society's benefit.

A phobia is an extreme and irrational fear. You could describe it as ignorance and fear combined. Society doesn't care if you're just afraid of spiders, that's your business. But if your phobia is of other people, you  are going to be inclined to act against them in anti-social ways. So yes, just as it's in society's interest to lessen ignorance, it's in society's interest to lessen irrational fears.

Comment: I believe that the burning up of Earth's fossil fuel resources just as quickly as possible is not a good idea.  I would like to include AGW as another reason to conserve but the AGW conjecture has many major flaws.  The AGW conjecture depends upon the existance of a radiant greenhouse effect attributed to the heat trapping effects of some trace gases with LWIR absorption bands.  The reality is that such a radiant greenhouse effect has not been observed anywhere in th solar system including the Earth.  As derived from first principals, the surface of the Earth is on average 33 degrees C warmer than it would be otherwise because of a convective greenhouse effect caused by gravity, the heat capacity of the atmosphere and the depth of the troposphere.  33 degrees C is the amount of warming derived from first principals and 33 degrees C is what has been observed.  Any additional warming caused by a radiant greenhouse effect has not been observed.  The AGW conjecture is science fiction.

Comment: I was expecting something more restrictive from the committee, so I'm pleasantly surprised that they delivered a more moderate set of recommendations. For example, I'm glad that they didn't follow the CMA's recommendation to set the minimum age at 25, which would've forced all young adults outside the legal market. However, the plain packaging requirement is unwise, and works against their goal to allow "craft" products, as plain packaging makes it difficult for new products to gain market share by outlawing branding and advertising.

And as always, the door has been left open for provinces to muck this up, and there's always the possibility the government could ignore the committee's report and implement something dumber.

Comment: "The difference between willingly risking one’s life and health in service of country and risking one’s life and health for the profits of tobacco companies is vast."

I do not know a single person who smokes for the express benefit of tobacco companies in the same way they serve in the military for the benefit of their country. Usually they smoke because they like to smoke. The RG's comparison is absurdly unhelpful.

I hate smoking, particularly when my neighbor does so on his porch for an hour at dawn, and his smoke drifts in my window as I try to cool my house. Even so, I prefer people have the right to make the decision to smoke for themselves once they are of reasonable age to know the consequences, which they certainly should by 18. However, they should not be able to force others to bear any part of the costs of that decision. Tobacco should be taxed at a rate to cover all health costs for its use. Those taxes should be held in a superfund which would reimburse health providers.

Comment: 1. Courts are not an 'unelected political body.'  It's an entire system of dispute resolution, sometimes leading to the voiding of laws or other government action.  In this respect, it's similar to what many, perhaps most other countries in the western world have.  Decisions are made on the basis of constitutional law.  No democratic country that I know of has an elected supreme court.

2. The Senate makes decisions on exactly the same basis as the elected House of Commons.  The only difference: they're unelected.  There may be another democratic country in the world with an unelected political assembly, but not that I can think of.

I realize you can't see the difference.

Comment: The battle cry of the French Revolution was "Liberty and Equality". In fact you can never have both completely. Outright liberty would lead to greater inequality. Outright equality would lead to less liberty. The dilemma is of course is where the right balance lies. That is the dilemma for governments everywhere. Those that insisted on complete equality only ensured that everyone was equally poor, i.e. the former Soviet Union, Cuba etc. (Although 'party members' were consistently better off.) They were a complete failure. At some point along the continuum of 'tax fairness' lies a tipping point of negative consequences. It seems that our current government is seeking that tipping point. Of course that is necessitated by spending more than the revenue allows and going into deficits. Our government has a spending problem not a revenue problem.

Comment: "The students in his classes are presumably able to understand statistical data and look up terms in Wikipedia, and the ones whose hands shoot up to try to catch him out on trivialities because they can't keep up in general probably shouldn't be there."

When I attended University graduating in '71 we had text books and many of us read ahead of the professor, using the lecture/classroom time to clarify points that we had not grasped on our own or in consultation with our peers.

I personally don't believe to this day that the existence of the Internet and a site like Wikipedia is an excuse for a poor or sloppy presentation by anyone.

I had an English professor who told the class on day 1, "you will submit 6 essays and I will give you a mark on the average of the best 5.  My 6th essay was a letter to the professor reminding him of my A average on my previous 5 submissions and trusting he would award me a mark based on my best 5 submissions...the letter was returned with an A+ :)

Comment: No, they didn't take the electoral college into account. They didn't have sufficiently detailed state level polling to do that, and Trump crossed the threshold in states he won by less than margin-of-error anyway.  

The EC projections were nothing more than a model - to address these known imprecisions, they take the data they do have (current polling and past election patterns) and run thousands of simulated elections, varying the parameters slightly with each mock run. The models predicted a Trump win about 10-20% of the time, an uncommon but not rare event. 

He won all three of his threshold states (MI, PA, WI) by under 1% of the vote, well below the sensitivity of polling.  This is not inconsistent with it being something of a statistical fluke - you wouldn't need to change a lot of votes (about 85,000, circa 1/4000 of America's population) to change the total outcome. . 

As a "comp sci grad" is it safe to assume you know what a bootstrap model is?

Comment: This point is incredibly important: the estimates should be debated before people get too excited.  

Property Taxes owed= Assessed Value times Tax Rate.  The article is correct if the tax rate does not change, but the tax rate is expected to change.  There is a reason why property tax rates are recalculated annually to six decimal places and have been falling over time (http://vancouver.ca/home-property-development/residential.aspx) while sales taxes are not.  The reason is explained in this video from the City of Vancouver http://vancouver.ca/home-property-development/property-tax.aspx  The same ideas apply in many other Canadian cities: the change in taxes owed depends mostly on the change in assessed value relative to other properties, not the absolute change.

Is it when movement is first detected? Quite possible. Is it once the fetus's organs and appendages are all present? Again, quite likely.
But what about mental/emotional development? Does a fetus have emotions/thoughts? Would it be terrified at the "thought" of being aborted or would it not realize at all what was happening? How would that be determined? In partial birth abortions when the spinal column is clipped, there is reportedly a jerking reaction in the baby. Is it purely the nervous system reacting? Is the baby reacting emotionally?
I don't know the answers to these questions and I'm not aware of there being any.

Comment: If he is not operating the junk yard as a business, then zoning laws don't necessarily apply. The City or State attempting to seize his property on his property because it looks bad is Un-Constitutional.  Since the area is zoned Residential, the neighbors need to establish a Home Owners Association and jurisdiction. This is a HOA issue not a MOA issue. Once the HOA is established the Board of directors must set a level of esthetics that are acceptable for owners in the HOA's Declaration. (Covenents)  Fines and fee schedules are typically set, with ability to lien on property to collect fees at sale or Title Transfer.   Until the HOA and Declaration are established; what looks good to you is simply your (or his) opinion.  Everybody has one..

Comment: I'm not being contrary Mr. Wohlforth but there are always two sides to a story. Do you know Gambell, the largest of two villages on St. Lawrence Island? If you know it was know as Sivuqaq until 1898. Do you know why the people adopted the new name? It was because of what happened to Rev. Vene Gambell, his wife Nellie and their daughter. They were returning to the island for their fourth year teaching aboard the schnooner Jane Gray carrying 32 souls when they encountered a violent storm and sank with no survivors. The Islanders had loved their school and their teachers. In fact their Siberian relatives were jealous and complained to the Russian government about a lack of schools in their villages. Education got off to a good start in this region. The entire state is not a disaster.
I'm OK with acknowledging past wrongs but the doers are mostly dead. Be best to try to engage village parents and children with the positive aspects of education rather than blaming ghosts.

He called it the "Night of the Long Knives” and we are still dealing with the fallout. He believed then that everything should stop and wait for him, and Quebec today still has the same sense of entitlement.

Comment: This opinion piece sounds like it was written by an intelligent 11th Grader.

I understand that the author has axes to grind, and that our First nations have been treated horribly over the past 150 years, but time moves on, and so does economic reality.

It is the "creative destruction" of the capitalist system. We may not like it, but the force is irreversible.  Railing against it is as effective as King Canute believing that he could hold back the tides.

Better to work with the system to improve what you can for your people (as many First Nations leaders have chosen to do, to better their communities) than rail against forces that will end up just running you over.

Comment: "But the kind of Canada the sun shines on? That’s up to us."

SHAME. The Pensions Industry – Government, Business, Media 

The government passed legislation indexing public service pensions. The gov't then underfunded the account. Actuarial cost was 4.7% of salary. The gov't deposited 1% then 2% of salary. By 1980 a deficit of $6 billion had developed. An ad appeared in the G&M saying you owe $6 billion to the special public service pension plan. The implication was that indexing was expensive. That was reinforced by editorials decrying how unfortunate it was that public sector pensions were indexed and private sector pensions were not. Too expensive.. 

The media did not mention the underfunding. 

Most despicable, the media and then the public, propagandized by the media, denigrate public servants for their indexed pensions. Business exploits pensioners by not indexing, saying too expensive. 

The pension industry, gov't, business and media are unconscionable. Canada’s shame.

Comment: The VA is more like an HMO than single payer - the doctors work directly for the VA.  With medicare you see any doctor who takes medicare (which is almost any doctor in the country if you have a decent supplemental plan).  If the VA would abandon the centralized VA run facilities and be more like medicare and let people see any doctor at any time and use any hospital, then and only then would it resemble single payer.  As it is now the VA resembles Kaiser (I don't mean to insult Kaiser - they're actually a great way to go if you have limited funds).  So looking at how well Kaiser is run and how poorly the VA is run sort of indicates that the VA management from top to middle levels needs to be replaced with people who actually know how to run things.

Comment: The Council of Trent was not an ecumenical council. It did not include bishops from the Eastern Church. It was small and limited to a select group of bishops which the Pope chose because he only wanted those bishops who agreed with him.

In 1530, when the Augsburg Confession was written, it was completely in line with the theology of the undivided church. There was nothing heretical about it. Calling a "council" of selectively chosen bishops in 1545 who were there only to oppose the Lutherans can't produce infallible teaching. Plus, there was no definition of what was and was not infallible teaching until Vatican I.

And--the Joint Declaration on Justification has thrown away the anathemas at Trent. Plus, Declaration on the Way has shown that much of what Trent said was based on misunderstandings and was time-bound.

After reading Declaration on the Way, what do you see as a mortal sin in someone moving to the Lutheran Church?

But what are assumptions if not faith that something unproven and possibly unprovable is actually truth? How is that any better than religious faith? The religious at least acknowledge they cannot prove their beliefs by scientific methods, which are not designed or intended to deal with philosophical constructs. But the science believers do not admit there are things science cannot prove upon which their entire belief system relies!

Science is very useful in helping us improve our lot in this world but supposing it disproves religious tenents is absurd.

Comment: Watch what's going on in California. An appeals court has ruled that while a public employee has a vested right to a pension, that right is only to a 'reasonable' pension, not an immutable entitlement to the most optimal formula for calculating the pension. As long as the legislature does not deprive the employee of a 'reasonable' pension, changes do not violate the constitution. This is a re-thinking of the famous 'California rule', and could have a significant impact around the country.

Comment: I would suggest that the current crossing safety measures are very adequate WITHOUT the train horns.  The issue is not that individuals don't know a train is coming.  The barriers are "down", the lights are flashing, the bells are ringing.  Persons who are struck by trains at such crossing knowingly disregard the existing warnings and barriers.  They're in a hurry and don't want to wait for "that damn train", so they drive around the barrier, ride their bike around it, or walk around it......after all they will "beat" the train to the crossing.  Breaking news: at such crossings the "tie" always goes to the train.

Those loud, obnoxious horns are appropriate and needed at rural crosssing where there are no barriers and,often, are no signals.  Having trains sound those horns at each crossing in a city is unnecessary.  Requiring millions of dollars to "up-grade" the crossings is unnecessary.  What's necessary?.......that people quit being so "stupid" in decisions to ignore the warnings...

Comment: You don't say wrote, "Let me get this straight, …you think a newspaper is required to report to you all things all the time."

.

No, Yds, I don't think "a newspaper" is required to report events based on my will or what I deem important. But I do think that if "a newspaper" expects to maintain the trust of its readership, based on the quality and breadth of its reporting (content), it had better adhere to a few simple principles in order to maintain trust (and readership). That includes reporting on local issues of interest, because omitting coverage of certain local issues would indicate a bias, or worse, an attempt to manipulate public opinion. Newspapers have operated based on some well defined editorial conventions and standards that have been codified over the course of the few years the U.S. republic has managed to survive.  For most of that time, those with money have tried to shape the news to their will.    Have another drink and think about that simple "reality" for a bit.

Comment: Doing a shelter on the cheap isn't going to work well. Not doing one at all clearly isn't working for Eugene, unless you live in the South Hills and can assuage your guilt by feeding the homeless who are preying on the residents of other neighborhoods (a problem largely caused by the ridiculous concentration of homeless services like camps all in one place).

We're way overdue to disperse our homeless by building several shelters on the south side and northeast portion of this city. Moderate numbers of homeless people can be helped in a neighborhood, but having 20% of the residents of a neighborhood be homeless will always fail everyone.

Added bonus: with shelters in place, we can crack down on the illegal camping that is destroying our parks and discouraging active transportation and lifestyles.

Comment: "the courage to stand up to Nixon's unconstitutional order"

It's never been established, and it's very unlikely, that Nixon's order to fire Cox was unconstitutional.

It's questionable whether a special prosecutor can be appointed by the Justice Department and yet be immune to dismissal by the President who has authority over the Justice Department.

It's highly questionable whether Congress has the constitutional power to demand, or pass laws requiring, special prosecutors. If the Congress wants to investigate, or take action against, a President their constitutional option is impeachment.

Presidents who have appointed (or ordered someone under their authority to appoint} special prosecutors have always faced political reaction and scandal - but have not gone beyond their constitutional powers.

But the political repercussions for a President in that circumstance range from loss of elections (for themselves or others in their party) up to and including impeachment and conviction

Comment: Thanks for a much more reasonable post, though I dispute ever being on a soapbox. Keeping views to ones self is reasonable in many situations, much more so than trying to tell someone else to keep their views to themself in a public forum, so thanks for the retraction, however backhanded. And having heartfelt respect for the opinions of others is an excellent policy, as long as disagreement is not taken as disrespect and if not phrased in a purposely disrespectful way. I make an effort to edit each of my comments for this kind of flaw each time before posting. Sometimes I am successful! We know more than we used to about what improves child dental health with least risk to the general population.  Most of the developed world has abandoned indiscriminate systemic dosage via water fluoridation, and the World Health Organization has reported that in developed nations, systemic fluoride dosing has no correlation to dental health. 

Port Angeles was fine with unfluoridated water until 2006, when a City Council that did many questionable things did one more, and without public notice signed a no-escape ten-year contract to add industrial fluoride compounds to our municipal water supply.  

At the end of the ten years, the current Council first proposed an advisory vote, then decided on a survey of all water customers, including those outside the City limits.  Two-thirds of them said "No" to fluoride  --  and the city overruled them.  This is not tin-hat nonsense.

It is interesting that the opinion refers to educators from pre-civil war days to bolster its premise.  Well, we know much has changed since those times.  The people cited by the author probably supported slavery and we should take their word for good educational policy?

The sad truth is that government run schools of today are much different from in years past.  Teacher's unions control the show and run up educational cost as well as controlling curriculum.   What DeVos suggests is public education, but her vision includes the possibility of privately run schools that operate via per student government payments.  Such schools, free from union control, could benefit all.

Comment: Nothing in my post suggests that Kauai residents pay the GET for rail. But just as Kauai residents shouldn't have to pay for rail (hence, "valid arguments"), so too is it dubious that Windward Oahu residents should.

The debate concerns whether the GET is an appropriate funding vehicle for rail, and there is no single proposal. You seem focused on one form that would preserve the existing surcharge for the City and County of Honolulu, but some suggest increasing the amount of that tax. These arguments are designed, as explicitly stated in my introduction, to respond to various proposals.

Moreover, there are various proposals for what should happen to the administrative fee. You're incorrect about the admin fee helping to pay the Department of Transportation's budget. The current fee collected goes into the state's general fund and is supposed to pay for the Department of Taxation, not Transportation. See the UHERO report: http://www.uhero.hawaii.edu/assets/Mak_RailSurcharge.pdf

Comment: This is the logical fallacy sometimes called "proving too much." It is refuted by reducing it to absurdity.

If anyone says that homosexuality is innate, he is making an assertion for which there is no evidence. But let us grant that for the moment.

If he then says that the innate trait of homosexuality cannot be a disorder "because God does not make mistakes," he commits the fallacy of "proving too much."

He is logically compelled to agree that if a baby is born without a brain, this is not a disorder "because God does not make mistakes."

Logically, he cannot demand funding for AIDS research, because AIDS cannot be a disorder, "because God does not make mistakes."

He must, logically, concede that the mere existence of ANY so-called "disorder, "disease," "deformity," or "infirmity" is proof that it is totally benign, because "God does not make mistakes."

In other words, "God does not make mistakes" is no proof that homosexuality is benign.

Comment: The so-called reduction is much less than the media is giving Wynne credit for.
Recall last year, that there was a 10% subsidy that has since been discontinued. This was replaced with a 8% subsidy (by removing provincial portion of HST). So this so-called 10% reduction is actually a 2% increase compared to last year. Then add to this the additional cap and trade increase that took effect in January (about an 8% increase, and you are left with an overall increase about 2%+8% = 10%. Now they are talking about changing amortization to reduce the bill by 15%. The net effect, the savings are just +10% - 15% = 5%. Yet they are marketing this as a 25% reduction. I wish the media would call this for what it is -- a paltry 5% reduction!

Comment: Comey did not say that "the Russians did not have any affect on any vote in the last election."
Here's the actual exchange:

BURR: Are you confident that no votes cast in the 2016 presidential election were altered?

COMEY: I'm confident. When I left as director I had seen no indication of that whatsoever.

"affected" and "altered" do not have the same meaning. Burr was asking about hacking of the electoral process itself, not about hacking of news sources, planting of fake news, and the use of bots to rapidly disperse fake news that was gobbled up by some right and alt-right media. Burr was not asking about whether the Russian disinformation campaign affected how people voted; his prepared question, which he read carefully, was about whether votes were altered after they were cast — and that's the question that Comey answered.

Comment: OCCG,
While theres some truth in what you say, you're missing one of the biggest components of what it means to be a human, and to be a Christian.

One need not have experienced war "on the front" to appreciate and learn from those who have.  There are TWO really big pieces that create the bridge that allows us to be human. Comment: Outsider:  It's tough to rewrite history, but I'll give you credit for trying.  The Southern economy was premised on slavery and the leaders perceived, probably correctly, that the end of slavery would cause a tremendous upheavel in Southern life...both culturally and economically.  Those leaders also perceived (again, likely very correctly) that, with the election fo Abraham Lincoln and the ever-growing power of the Abolitionist movement, slavery in the U.S. was coming to an end....and likely in the near future.  Rather than seek to negotiate as favorable a transition as possible, likely including compensation for emancipated slaves, the South chose to secede.  It's no surprise that most the young men in the South chose to support secession. They were raised in the South and slavery was part of the values system of their lives.  ....and, yes, those damn Yankees were going to end slavery.  Gary Crum

Comment: There is an assumption that the values of real estate will keep on increasing. This is most likely not the case. We bought our condo in Vancouver in 1993. For the first 10 years the real estate values did not increase. Then they slowly went up , and over the past two years went up very fast. But over the 24 years, the return on investment in real estate in Vancouver has averaged about 6% a year, which is no different from the return that could have been collected from other investments. In conclusion the present situation of very fast increases will probably not last, a few people will make a lot of money and many more will lose or be disappointed with the returns.

Comment: Re lack of OR time, the issue boils down to money in a simple way. To stay in budget, what is the ONE thing a hospital can cut back on? Elective surgery - can't stop emergencies happening, can't stop people getting sick or delivering their babies, but you can make people wait longer for their hip replacement. An orthopedic surgeon I used to refer patients to told me he had one day a month in the OR - not enough for him to keep up his own skills, never mind provide the service his patients required.
A horrifying percentage of health care money now goes to administration. Tell them it's too much and what do they do? - hire a new manager (plus assistant and support staff) to see how patient care can be cut back further without touching the holy admin budget.
I can't defend doctors who double-dip where it is expressly forbidden by law, but while that's a crime, preventing it won't make a difference to health care funding issues; there's far more money being wasted on self-serving managers.

Comment: The habit of holding women in subservience has been with us a long time, and in many places. It has for most of recorded history been one of the most reliable features of social orders. 

The Church's repudiation of slavery came quietly, and only after the civil authorities of the world's largest Catholic country had finally ruled it a crime. While individuals within the Church took virtuous stands, in various times and places, the institution itself did not rise to its feet 'till that struggle was over.  

In 300 years, perhaps Fr. Orobator will be cited as a proof that the Church has forever taught the true equality of men and women, a few errant homilies notwithstanding. God's blessings on him, and those he loves.

Comment: The story of some drug-smuggling Mexican Mennonites, descendants of "Old Colony" Mennonites who had first immigrated to western Canada from Russia (migrating to Russia from Dutch-Prussian regions areas previously) in the 1870s is factual. However, presenting them in the garb and customs of the "Old Order" Mennonites who settled in Ontario and the eastern parts of the U.S. from the Swiss-South German regions of Europe beginning in the late 18th C. is to completely garble the story and the history of the respective peoples. Ethnically, they are different people. Linguistically, they speak different dialects of German. Of course, the producers may not care about authenticity at all, and felt that the audience would be disappointed at the relatively normal appearance of the Mexican Mennonites so they went for the more quaint Old Order look. People might want to watch this series, but they should do so understanding it is entertainment, not an accurate presentation of events or peoples.

Comment: "What is needed is to make taxation fair by simply saying that if you get $ from a source, ANY SOURCE, then it will be taxed in the same way with NO BREAKS, DEDUCTIONS, OR EXEMPTIONS."
.
That is where you went off the rails. For example, take a retailer who makes $100K in sales of merchandise that cost him $80K, and he has another $10K in overhead costs. By your argument, he should be taxed on the $100K gross receipts rather than the $10K profit. Most people would argue that is anything BUT fair. On the other hand, if you agree that he should be taxed on the $10K, your emphatic prohibition is out the window. 
.
The idea that wage earners, heirs, investors, game winners, etc. should be taxed at the same rate for a given level of income is defensible, even reasonable. The idea that we should eliminate all adjustments to taxable income is neither.

Comment: In Response to: Civil Comments Discriminates

No, I do not dispute that wolves roam throughout  Denali’s non-glaciated 6 million acres; what I dispute is that they enjoy full, Federal protection throughout those acres that those in the hunting/trapping community claim is the case. It is not and hasn’t been since ANILCA was passed in 1980 and the 4 million acres of Preserve/New Additions were added. 

In an ideal world, ANILCA would have included those protections and the Wolf Townships (identified decades ago by Adolf Murie as being critical caribou/wolf habitat) would have been included, but that is not the case. Also, in an ideal world, decisions would be based on maintaining biological integrity of all species and ecosystems, visitor viewing, enjoyment, appreciation and education and the inherent economic benefits that would come about by this. Furthermore, intangible benefits would also be included - unfortunately that is not the case.

Comment: yes:  you rank the candidates from 1 to whatever you choose.....votes are counted.....candidate w/least votes is eliminated and his/her votes go to the #2 choice.  This continues until you establish a majority-vote candidate.  It really opens up the process for third party and independent candidates by removing the issue of "wasted" votes if they are cast for such candidates.  It would lessen the strangle-hold the two major parties have on our electoral process.  Which means, of course, that it's very unlikely to ever  be adopted.   regards, Gary Crum

Comment: "The exception is parents who want to deny their children life-saving procedures, usually on religious or cultural grounds. They should be overruled."

You can't grant courts authority in those cases but deny it in cases where the shoe is on the other foot. Either they get involved in medical decisions or they don't; you can't choose cases to get the decisions you want. Since there are many situations where we can all agree that a court must step in to protect a patient, we are stuck with courts being, potentially, involved in all kinds of medical decisions. In this particular case, Great Ormond Street (one of the best paediatric hospitals in the world) must feel very strongly that there is a clear case of excess suffering being imposed on a hopeless case for them to take the unusual step of asking to override the parents' wishes. It seems very unlikely that any treatment can 'bypass mitochondrial function' and any benefit is still likely to leave the child vegetative on a ventilator.

Comment: On no!  Laws might change!  

Not to worry.  Why not to worry?

Try thinking of a law that the majority (read:  the MAJORITY) of the public want abolished, immediately.
Anything from the smallest traffic laws to any law debated by SCOTUS.

There are none.   The reason?   In a democracy, lawmakers invariably only enact laws that the majority will agree with and abide.  And any law that the majority of citizens disagrees with cannot long stand.  This has been true since our nation's founding.

We assume that we're at the mercy of our lawmakers.  But actually, our  lawmakers heed public opinion more than abstract legal reasoning.  

So if you're worried that abortion will be outlawed,  it's simply not going to happen.   

Why?  Because since 1970, the percentage of the public who want abortion outlawed has always been less than 20%.   That is the true reason for why abortion is legal -- majority opinion of the public.  Particular judges only seemed like the reason.

Comment: The tricks in charity are legion.  The most obvious and common scam is donating goods in kind (art and other collectibles especially).  A receipt far in excess of the value of the goods is issued and both parties walk away happy.  

Registered charities needn't pay tax on the proceeds of the sale, so even if they issue a 10K receipt for a piece of art that only sells for 500, they are still 500 ahead.  And the wealthy donor has earned him or herself a 3300 dollar deduction.

Individuals and charities have both been caught doing this, but if they  don't get too greedy about it things generally pass under CRA's radar .  As the old saying goes, pigs get fat but hogs get slaughtered.

Comment: Obviously, you're dismissing anything the deniers say.  That's not good science.  Hear them out.  They make a lot of good points.  I've listened to both sides for over 25 years, and the deniers make a better case.  Nothing the hysterics predicted over 2 decades ago has come to pass.  Their models have been wrong about everything.

The two primary drivers of Climate Change are the Earth's distance from the sun in it's elliptical orbit, and the cycle of sun spot activity.  Your charlatan's don't consider either.

The Maunder Minimum, which occurred between about 1450 and 1850, was an unusually long period of low sun spot activity, and when it began to pick back up in the middle of the 17th century, it began to warm.  The CO2 level didn't begin to rise for another 200 years.  We're coming off a "mini-ice age," and we have  a long way to go to get back to normal CO2 levels.

I beg to differ that you're rational.

Comment: That's a fair question.  My reading is that Francis is trying to do what Jesus (not very successfully) tried to do.  We all understand that Jesus was not preaching the law but its fulfillment in the reign of God.  Sadly, much of what Jesus said was interpreted as if he were preaching the law -- law on steroids, perhaps, but law nonetheless.

The four cardinals want Francis to preach the law, as well.  He's not doing that.  The law applies generally, to all.  What Francis is looking to do is cultivate fulfillment of the law.  That's hard to do, but the discernment process can go in that direction if conscience connects up to God's law "written on the human heart".  

Francis said what he wanted in "Amoris Laetitia".  What the four cardinals call "doubt and confusion" is neither.  You don't have discernment if the results of every discernment have to be rationalized as law.  The role of the pastor is to help conscience connect to Christ, not to conform conscience to the law.

Comment: Either you value your time more than your money (and you'll be willing to pony up $$$ to drive in the toll lane with no delays), or you value your money more than your time, and you'll drive in the free lane even if it means it takes you twice as long to get where you're going. The point is, it is about CHOICE, and anybody is free to use either lane depending on whether they value their time more than their money, or vice-versa. Maybe you're a millionaire but you're retired and in no rush, and want to drive in the free lane even if it takes an extra half-hour. Maybe you're a minimum wage worker and you absolutely need to get to your job on time, or you'll be fired, and you pay the 8 bucks (an hour's worth of work). There is no right or wrong answer, just make the best choice for yourself.

Comment: Mostly a useless device that tracks all sorts of body responses, often inaccurately, that has the potential to create hypochondriacs when they see natural variations in blood pressure, heart rate, sleep quality etc. that are perfectly normal.

Comment: Let's make the contention of this article a little simpler: by removing the ability for business owners to split their income via dividends distributed to family member-shareholders, business owners are in effect seeing an increase in their personal / family marginal tax rates. In an effort to appear reasonable, the business owner was fine with the last increase (and with progressive taxation in general), but not this one. 

This is a disagreement about the appropriate rate of taxation on marginal income for business owners, rather than a disagreement about progressive taxation itself. 

This article, however, does not make any case about what a reasonable level of taxation is, only that this new higher level is presumably not it. We're left with an emotional appeal (this business owner deserves to profit from their hard work!) without any analysis of what an appropriate level should be.

Comment: Kiszla seems to have jumped to a premature conclusion that Siemian is as good as he will ever be. Accumulation of experience still makes a difference in the NFL, especially where quarterbacks are concerned. 

It is also too early to dismiss Lynch as a bust. Should Siemian have a good, but not great year in 2017, the two players could easily be competing again for the starting job next year. Perhaps the light goes on for Lynch in year three. Drew Brees was considered a bust prior to his breakout season in 2004 (his fourth NFL season). It's way to early to call either Siemian or Lynch anything other than works in progress. 

I hope Siemian emerges this year as the answer at QB. If he doesn't, Lynch will get another chance in 2018. Add the intriguing Kyle Sloter and a healthy-by-then Chad Kelly to the mix, and that's a fascinating quarterback competition next year.

Comment: Everybody talks about rates and loopholes (deductions), but very few try to identify how income is to be calculated.  For the salaried worker, it is simple.  But, for the small business owner, it can get very complicated very quickly.  How does one get from gross income to net income?  What expenses should be subtracted?

Then, another area of the tax code that is very complicated, is defining who qualifies as a dependent?  Once again, for most taxpayers, this is simple.  But when one starts to review the possibilities, it becomes complicated and a mistake can easily be made.

For a large majority of tax payers, the above cause no problems.  However, there is still a large percentage of taxpayers that have to deal with these issues.  There may not be an easy way to simplify the tax code for these taxpayers.

Comment: Compulsory pay equity reporting by companies could make systemic discrimination easier to detect and prosecute. But any "pay gap" must be measured job-for-job. 
That the total pay of all women is 74% annually or 88% hourly of the total pay of all men completely sidesteps the issue of equal pay for equal work. At best such statistics might indirectly measure the gender distribution of paid work. In the STEM fields that women have only recently begun to populate, the $9100 "pay gap" most likely reflects that the senior jobs are still male dominated. Come back to us when you can prove job-for-job inequality. 
Is Trudeau's arbitrary gender equality for his cabinet the model business should follow? Shame on the electorate for not electing a gender-balanced House of Commons. 
It's time to face the facts: All legal barriers to equality have been removed and discrimination outlawed. Equality cannot be legislated, it must be achieved. Stop whining and get on with it!

Comment: People can fret about a lack of proportional representation in Canada, but at least we have never had a Prime Minister from a party that did not get the most votes.  The US has had 2 such elections in the past 5 (both Republican).  The national elections there are somewhat gerrymandered.  The congressional ones are far more so, to the point that this happens regularly.

Now, the last Prime Minister probably would have had the majority of the voters rank him last place on the ballot in 2011 (had we bothered to do that).  That's a bit of a problem for us.

Comment: Working as a processor is hard work, 26 years ago I was pull off a ship in Dutch harbor and flown to anchorage. A meeting with Senator Ted Steven's and Harvey Samuelson sr. - we talked about jobs opportunities for people living in western Alaska communities also the trash and debris from at sea bottom trawlers. This meeting during the North Pacific fishery management council would open up a lot of opportunities for western Alaska communities. Contracts back then were 120 days and 16 hrs a day. Sleeping conditions and the food had no complaints. During my 13 complete contacts I seen up to one third of the workers leave when we off load at Dutch harbor or Kodiak .I almost quit a few times - Harvey encouraged me to keep working, , the CDQ program did not come on a silver platter and was thought up when I was sorting pollack , look at all the opportunities the $$ the CDQ program has to offer. Ideas on how to invest in higher pay for CDQ residents also do value-added to keep the jobs here.

Comment: Matt, I know a bit about this topic as well, having dealt with and managed my share of chronic pain patients--who are also, necessarily, addicts--over my 30 year career.   You're correct that most physicians aren't specifically trained in pharmacology.  However, they ARE highly trained professionals in whatever field they select, including the field of pain management.   Including a 4 year undergraduate degree, which is required by the federal government, it takes 8 years to become a pharmacist. Depending on the speciality and including undergraduate requirements,  physicians can take up 15 years or longer to become an M.D.  
I certainly won't argue that there are some bad apples out there but the majority of pain specialists are legitimate and serve a legitimate patient population.  I don't countenance witch hunts and that is my concern with all the finger pointing going on these days.  The entire medical establishment, law enforcement and our governments are largely responsible.

Comment: Because  Western governments backed the losing side in Aleppo, our media has been all over the battle for the city. They've essentially ignored what's going on in the fight to reclaim Mosul from Islamic State. But if you dig around you can find some information, and things are not going well. Islamic State is putting up a fierce resistance. UN reports state that the Iraq army lost 2000 soldiers last month in the battle. No doubt Islamic State has lost a lot of fighters too. Nevertheless, the intensity of the battle for Mosul appears to be far greater than that for Aleppo. That will surely mean that civilian losses are likewise greater.

To put it in context, the battle for Aleppo took the lives of about 500 fighters on BOTH sides over the last month. If Iraq did indeed lose 2000 soldiers in Mosul over the same period, it's reasonable to assume that civilians losses are at least four times as high as well.

Comment: The so called "postcard" filing is actually a replacement for Form 1040EZ.  Some of us might already be familiar with that form.  For just about everyone else, it's filing as usual.

Here's our two cents on the proposed 15% tax on flow through income.  This 15% rate would make sense for those of us who are small business owners, who need the tax relief.  So, if you are a small business owner struggling to grow your business and are currently taxed at 25% or even 28%, that makes good sense.  

However, if this 15% rate on flow through income is allowed for those already wealthy persons who would be at the proposed top tax bracket of 35%, that amounts to a 20% reduction in tax rate (35% - 15% = 20%) on that income.  

Why do the wealthiest Americans need such a large tax break in the first place?  And believe it, the wealthy do get substantial amounts of flow through income.  Btw, the current tax plan gives the wealthiest Americans even more tax breaks.  Who pays for all of that, anyway?

Comment: This is more common than you may think.  I was 1 of 4 Jewish kids in a large high school in eastern PA.  The amount of crap I took from teachers and/or administrators because I am not Christian was pretty damn frustrating.  That crap was everything from being sent to detention for not wanting to sing Christmas songs praising Jesus as a part of a required Christmas pageant, to being told pointedly that I would fail a class if I missed a day for the Jewish High Holidays.  Those holidays happen early enough in the school year that there is no way I wouldn't be able to make up the work, but since the teacher had scheduled a test for that day, with no way to make it up, I was out of luck as far as he was concerned.  Thankfully, my parents are both incredibly pushy and managed to make most of the problems go away without resorting to suing.

As for the Christmas songs, I would have been fine if they had been the secular Rudolph and Santa type songs, but not full on religious ones.

Comment: On June 4, 1977 the Alaska enacted the Alaska Coastal Management Act (ACMA), which established the Alaska Coastal Management Program (ACMP).
The ACMP was composed of 33 coastal resource districts which develop and implement their own programs and enforceable policies for the roughly 44,500 miles of Alaska coastline, which has national and international significance for its healthy and diverse ecosystems.
The intent of the ACMP was to provide stewardship for Alaska’s rich and diverse coastal resources to ensure a healthy and vibrant coast that efficiently sustains long-term economic and environmental productivity. It was also intended to provide a forum for local community involvement in the preservation and development of our coastal areas through the participation of the district programs.
Frank Murkowski started the destruction of ACMP.
Sean Parnell and the Republican Legislature killed it dead in 2011, making Alaska the only state where coastal communities lost their voice.

Comment: Yep.  Red-eared sliders (Trachemys scripta elegans) already overwinter here.  For now it seems doubtful our warm weather will prove either warm enough or long enough for them to successfully reproduce. And you misunderstood my use of 'irresponsible.'  I'm saying release of non-native species into the environment is irresponsible.  Period.  And have enough examples to demonstrate that it isn't 'subjective', but a logical assessment of a predictable outcome in the vast majority of cases.

Example--AK F&G lists the bullfrog (Rana catesbeiana) as a potentially harmful species should it be introduced, for several very good reasons.  They are asymptomatic carriers of Batrachochythrium dendrobatis, a deadly fungus which is eliminating amphibian species worldwide.  They also prey on smaller species and have caused extreme declines in native frog species in the western US.  To predict their introduction here would prove harmful to native wood frogs (R. sylvatica) isn't 'subjective'.  At all.

Comment: I agree with Elizabeth Renzetti, though I don't understand why the word "phobia" must be so prominent in the matter. In my experience "phobia" means fear. A quick online search gives a range of meanings from "fear," through "intense fear" to "hatred." That's a huge difference. My thick, weathered Collins Dictionary sticks with degrees of fear but does not mention hatred. Therefore the meaning of "phobia" tends toward fear, in my opinion, and I do not understand how one can condemn  that.

When I consider my own intense fears - dying from suffocation, heights, coming eye-to-eye with a water creature under water - it occurs to me that condemning them would only make me feel frustrated and misunderstood.

So yes, please, get the thing going. But keep the word "phobia" out of the title, and work to improve the wording right from the start.

We live with fear like we live with cancer, and I don't think condemnation is the way out of either. In both cases I'd go with "healing," though/

Comment: There will be some hand wringing about sourcing steel for Keystone from US sources. Did anybody note the big loophole in Trump's declaration?..........use US products "to the maximum extent possible". This is a loophole large enough to run 3,000km of large diameter pipe through. TRP could play with the specs of the Keystone pipe so as to make most US suppliers ineligible. Not so many US manufacturers have the capability to produce 48" heavy wall tubes. US Steel, for example, does not have that capability. Grade of steel could be another sticking point.

The coating part of the contract would also be problematic for US companies. There is no company in USA that has a coating plant with the capabilities of Shawcor's newer plant in Camrose, AB; a plant that is just across the street from the 48" pipe forming mill owned by Evraz Camrose.

For all of his self-declared expertise at negotiating business deals, I think that Trump may be not quite so adept as he thinks.

Comment: I think this thesis has merit within a small sub-section of entrepreneurship.  Business is not about risk-taking or innovation.  Business is about capturing, sustaining, and increasing market share.  Risk-taking and innovation are just certain means to that end.

Canadian's have proven time and again that we are excellent early entrepreneurs, idea generators, early adopters etc.  I would argue our weakness is in implementation, execution, and strategic management.  In other words, we don't need more entrepreneurs we need more highly effective managers and workers.

Our current culture is at risk of falling into the Tech founder worship syndrome.  Sustaining market share, defending and increasing market share through strategic management decisions, executing those decisions.  These are the foundations of long-term prosperity. A queen-size bed is about 3 m² in area. The prism of air between the top sheet and the top of the atmosphere contains 18 kg of CO2 (a queen-size down duvet contains about 1 kg of down, for comparison). But since you like numbers, that 18 kg of CO2 consists of 240,000,000,000,000,000,000,000,000 molecules, each and every one of them capable of absorbing infrared radiation.

Comment: Alexandra,
I have long tried to be an "independent," although I will readily admit that in terms of politics, I lean right, while in terms of social justice, I lean a bit to the left.  Those ARE my biases, and I don't think I've ever tried to hide them.  My wife and I have tended to be TV news junkies for a while now, and I HAVE seen a lot of what I will call "screaming."

I don't profess to be a constitutional scholar, but while I law school I DID tend to load up on constitutional law classes.  So I DO find it more than a little amusing to listen to the punditry and commentators talk about the constitution and what it does/does not say.

As to "screaming," all you need to is to tune into the evening news to see it, daily.  My point is that we need to get past that, and back to respectful disagreement in society.    

As to the nuclear option, much ado about nothing.  The "60-vote" threshold is a senate rule, relatively recent at that.  It required civility in Congress to work.

Comment: From very young ages, my 4 kids had first hand visuals of the mortality and devastating trauma caused by guns on game animals. The cute bunny, deer, bear, etc. laying lifeless with a bloody hole in it. And it didn't get up to star in the next movie. Still, to the chagrin of my peers, I never let them point toy guns (or even their fingers) at a human and say "POW!" No squirt gun fights, playing 'Army', 'Cops and Robbers', 'Cowboys and Indians' or Grand Theft Auto type video games (These came out later and as "adults" they played them anyway...). And I screened (to the best of my ability) their intake of movies and TV. Perhaps I was viewed as a hard ass, but, I know first hand that it sucks to be shot. Yet, guns have always been an important tool in my life and I'm not one to throw out a hammer over a black thumbnail. I've kept them handy and I've kept them loaded. If you haven't taken the time to discipline your children before getting a gun, maybe you should get a baseball bat instead.

Comment: This isn't about "I could have made more on XYZ" or "I lost money on ABC".

It is about why all Advisor55's clients have remarkably similar portfolio holdings?  Or why the clients at a particular firm seem to gravitate to a particular investment product?  Or why are the average fees collected on investment products sold significantly higher for a particular adviser or firm? 

In other words the fiduciary duty isn't about preventing mistakes or decisions that in hindsight could have been managed differently. But rather about preventing deliberate and systematic actions on the part of the advisor and firm to promote investment decisions that weren't in the client's best interest.

I pity the client whose adviser isn't able to distinguish the difference.

Comment: Actually, Canada does screen both immigrants and refugee claimants.  Objectively speaking, it does a rather good job at this and several other countries are adopting and adapting key elements of our program in this regard.

On the other hand, there is the false hope that some "cultural values" screening criteria should be added as a key element of our screening process.  At first blush, many may well think that such sentiments (really a Rorschach Inkblot that takes different forms in the eye of each beholder) might be reduced to concrete form (i.e. Isn't the Criminal Code, participation in xenophobic groups,  concrete evidence of moral turpitude or such like criteria enough?) to good effect.  However, as the last Quebec and Federal General Elections amply illustrate, such efforts only lead to confusion, frustration and greater social anxiety all around.

Comment: When electronic ignitions began to become popular in autos in the 1980's auto makers began shielding ignitions system,  not from an EMP, but from auto mechanics or auto owners causing static discharge from connecting, dis-connecting battery cables or from nearby lightning strikes. They did not want to deal with warranty problems from dead ignitions systems. Ever since then, the auto makers have been shielding the solid state electronics in vehicles to protect them. Often the computer is buried on the firewall and very well shielded. An EMP isn't going to effect many vehicles. Many other electronic devices will survive as well.  This article is just more fear mongering.

Comment: We live on a nice medium priced street here in Mississauga. One agent sold 7 homes for an average of 1 million per sale. Times that amount of sales by 5% and he took home gross, $350,000.00. He owns the brokerage as well. By our reckoning each sale was over asking and the longest sale took two weeks. We know he staged a couple of homes at about $3,500.00 per home. All of his sales were as a result of referrals because he told us. 
Did this agent merit a $350,000 payday for this amount of work? Clearly not. I'll give the agent credit for working his contacts but all of his sales were to Asian families and this agent was not Asian. But he does advertise in Asian newspapers. Some people are lucky because of circumstances. It's been this way in Mississauga for 35 years. Used to be the fastest growing city in Canada. Now its almost built out so real estate sales are mostly second or third upgrades. Talk about good timing.

Comment: The suspect's criminal record. He or she created that record and he or she can, at a subsequent   bail hearing, come to understand the consequences of their choices.  Because a judge can hold persons without bail he or she obviously has access to the that criminal record. Bail for professional criminals does not serve the intended purpose of allowing a citizen to remain productive until his or her case is resolved in a court of law.  The State Legislature can (within constitutional limits) create further restrictions . Also addiction and mental illness are not addressed by a bail bond. Comment: HSTA's intent is genuine, but It would be futile to increase funding for public education with the surcharge that it proposes.  The Legislature would be able to use that money for other purposes , simply by reducing the regular funding for education and using the "savings" for something else.  That's what ultimately happened in other jurisdictions when taxes on proposed casinos were designated for education.

It would be wiser for HSTA or anyone else interested in improving the quality of public education to reform the system and restructure it to make it more effective.  The DOE's existing structure is stuck somewhere in the 19th century.  

Charter schools are showing the way.  Like regular schools, the success of charter schools is mixed.  However, there is a significant difference in funding.  The charter school per pupil allocation is about $6,100, while the overall per pupil support for public schools is $11,500.  If charter schools received more, they would be able to do more.

Comment: I'm an Eagle Scout, class of 1991, I was also an Assistant Scout Master for several years and started with Cub Scouts. While in Cub Scouts it was an expectation of Scouts to learn how to participate in political discourse. We would attend City Council, Board of Education, State Legislature or meet with local representatives. Any question was acceptable, regardless of the base political view, so long as the question related to a policy topic, speech or platform of the speaker (basically, "where did you buy your suit?" was not permitted). This question was a relevant topic, the answer was also relevant. Being dismissed from the Den for such an inquiry is on the Den Leader, not the Local or National Office of the BSA. The Den Leader needs to demonstrate the reasons for dismissal that violated the Scout Code, Scout Law or were egregious insults to the speaker or other Scout or family. If the Leader cannot do that, they should not have position.

Comment: This article did bring out a couple of important points about the complexity of calculating actions. The sequestration concept is one that gets ignored when people look at only a very short term release. To compare the carbon input of lighting or fossil fuel that has been sequestered for millions of years to the short term ups and down that are measured in days to decades of agricultural activities is misleading.  When the long term sequestered products are added to the normal biological actives is where problems come in.
The ecological impact is also not accounted for.  The ecological impact of cutting rainforest for grazing is large but the replacement of grazers is small and may be positive in terms of ecology.  Many square miles of monoculture beans or oats is harmful to the environment so grass feed beef is better than feel lot beef but it may also be better for the environment than people consuming beans and oats from massive monoculture.

Comment: Legally, it does not matter "who came first".  Nor does it matter that home owners and other residents may be unhappy with drilling and production operations.  What does matter is that surface rights and mineral rights for many land parcels were severed in the past.  And state law grants priority access to the mineral rights (i.e. the surface owner cannot prevent access to the subsurface).

If home owners, and their representatives, are surprised by this, they can only blame themselves.

Trying to change the laws now is of course possible, but will likely be both unsuccessful and expensive.

Comment: I still fail to see how kneeling during the National Anthem is disrespectful. Colin Kaepernick wasn't turning his back on the flag. He didn't make crude gestures. He wasn't yelling. He kneeled.
I would argue a law requiring that "All persons residing in the United States of America or its territories and trusteeships WILL stand during any playing of National Anthem and they WILL place their right hand over their upper-left chest and they WILL remove any cap, hat, helmet, or other headgear -- or else!" is unAmerican.
The NFL is free to hire or refuse to hire or fire as its teams see fit -- just ask Michael Sam. Colin Kaepernick is no exception. He is not guaranteed an NFL job. But, I think the reaction over his kneeling is way overblown.
Patriotism is more than standing for the National Anthem. Patriotism is more than wearing a flag pin on one's suit jacket or blouse. It's also about upholding our values. And one of those values is dissent.

Comment: Quote: "How on earth was the democratic process preserved through court order trumping the vote?"
The referendum was only advisory. Britain is a parliamentary representative democracy. Parliament decides.
The role of supreme courts is to ensure that the actions of governments respect the constitution or existing laws that are equivalent to a constitution.
So in this case the referendum may have been democratic, but that is only one part of the picture. The following actions by the government did not respect the laws that make up the "constitution" of the country, according to the Supreme Court.

The animals are not frightened, slipping on their own blood, etc, that's AR propaganda.  Animals that release adrenaline prior to processing do not produce good meat, therefore it is in the best interest of these processing plants to keep animals calm.  It's over before they know it.  Involuntary twitching after death is common, but the animals feel no pain. I love my animals, but I do know their purposes.

I choose to look positively at Trump's candidacy and understand the needs and fears of those who are voting for him. It is easy to mock him, but there are going to be millions of Americans who will go out of their way to vote his way, not because they are evil, bigoted, sexist,  racists, but because they are afraid and angry. Trump has pretty much garnered the vote of those displaced in the employment jungle by what they see as unregulated immigration and uncaring businesses moving to China. 
So write a column acknowledging their needs and despair, write a column saying what the US needs to do alleviate their fear and anger. To mock Trump is to mock the millions who listens to him because he is the only one in either party who champions them. 
(Well, I will be voting for Bernie, as I understand what he is saying, but Democrats don't do a very good job relating to non-college educated blue collar workers who have lost out in this new, brutal America).
Hugh Massengill, Eugene

Comment: I read your letter before my morning coffee.  Your comment about doing more with less is a falacy.  Doctors, Nurses, therapists and technicians of all kinds have the right to expect salaries that reward them for the years they spent in school and other training and the experiences they have from years of practice.  Sutures cost the same, no matter if you are placing them in a Single Payer patient or one whose care is paid for by a for profit health care plan.  Hospital rooms cost a lot to build supply and staff.  The amount that people think they can save by eliminating profits are in the single digits of percents and are guesses.  If you saved two or three or four percent at your job, you would only be able to do a little more.  There are not enough savings that might be had by doing away with private insurance to fill the current gap between available care and demand.  The theory that there would be is right out of Reaganomics.

Comment: I'm probably more in the camp of Prof. Cantu and, like him, I doubt I'll get much applause here. 

I promise you, nobody opposed the election of Donald Trump more than I did or was as sickened (literally) by his election. But that said, he was legally elected. The popular vote differential makes for a nice argument against a mandate, but not against his legitimacy. And yes, Russia influenced the election and only the most die-hard Trumpistas don't get that. But unless somebody can prove that Putin stuffed ballot boxes, it won't change anything.

The bottom line is, the guy was elected and all the protests in the world won't make us wake up from that nighmare. So I'm going to hold my nose and try to get through the next four years, supporting policies I agree with (if any) and biding my time until 2020.

But if Trump does happen to do something impeachable, which I fully expect, I'll be on it like white on rice.

Comment: They are Convention refugee claimants - asylum seekers are a completely different category under Canadian immigration terminology. The latter are persons seeking protection but not for the reasons set out in the definition of a Convention Refugee and are very rare.

The law on refugees (including Canadian precedents) does not preclude them from making a refugee claim even if they have spent time in the US.  Our courts have ruled that time spent in a safe third country is not determinative of the claim but the Refugee Protection Division are entitled to look at a claimant's path to Canada to determine if the claimed persecution is well-founded.

Any claimants who are determined not to be refugees will be returned to their home countries - not the US unless they had legal status in the US which seems unlikely

Comment: Your statements above are examples of sloppy thinking.
Your statement "we have made a habit in American politics of not voting for a candidate we believe in but instead voting against the candidate we fear" is simply nonsense.

If you have only two real choices for play in a game and you aren't completely sold on the first choice but are dead set against the second, it would be idiocy to exit the game and engage in imaginary play in an imaginary game that no one is actually playing. 
I challenge your claim: "its our tolerance of the lesser evil, of the less corrupt politician that has perpetuated an ever increasing parade of horrible political candidates." You have no choice BUT to tolerate it unless you choose not to play the game.

Comment: Marty Kendall is an engineer whose (then) young son became type one diabetic. He has done some excellent data analysis work and has derived a useful formula for estimating the insulin load of different foods (optimisingnutrition.com/2016/05/02/insulin-load-the-greatest-thing-since-carb-counting/#_ftn1): 

    insulin load = total carbohydrates – fibre + (0.56 x protein)

As you can see, fat is not a material factor. Or as Dr. Jason Fung puts it (on his blog intensivedietarymanagement.com/dietary-fat-hyperinsulinemia/): "Simply put, dietary fat does not raise insulin."

They cite references. I have seen other references that put the relative insulin index of carbs at 100 and dietary fat at 2. (It might be Dr. David Ludwig. I would have to search.)

Comment: JSB1, the legality of states requiring tax returns for presidential candidates to get on a ballot is debatable and has been debated by constitutional law experts. Many believe it would be constitutional because it does NOT impose a qualification over and above the federal government, but merely requires the provision readily and easily providable information. The Supreme Court case that is always cited, "U.S. Term Limits v. Thornton" DID add an actual qualification to be on the ballot: candidates could not have served more than three or more terms in Congress. The release of tax returns makes no requirement as to what the returns show; that judgement would be up to the individual voter. Not surprisingly, conservative-leaning experts believe this would still be unconstitutional and a liberal-leaning experts believe it would be perfectly constitutional. We may get to see what the Supreme Court thinks at some point.

Comment: baptistry is an octagonal pool ; the floor is a  mosaic kind of like a cosmic burst with rays radiated from the center..some the color of water,and some more like light with gold and silver tiles.  The front gate leads to steps to enter the water.  Person kneels in the water up to mid thighs or so  and using Bishop Maes' (who built the cathedral) water pitcher, water is poured copiously over their head... a really good soaking, but not full immersion. On the side opposite of the gate we installed the original baptistry  carved from a single piece of marble  with baptismal symbols---an octagon--quite beautiful again preserving our heritage with a creative reuse.  Water flows continuously from the original  into the pool. The upper font is used for infants. I think the current bishop and rector only use the upper font even for adults.  Also built an ambry adjacent with glass doors so one could see the oils...quarter sawn oak matching other wood throughout church.   It has been removed.

Comment: About time.  
All B&B operators should charge the tax.  Some do.  Many do not.
The primary difference between Air BnB and Home Away (VRBO) is that the operator pays a fee to Home Away for the listing.  Then customers call directly to book.  This puts the onus of collecting the tax on the individual operator.  As the municipality has no sales tax they have no means of auditing.
With Air BnB, all booking and payments happen through the site so the tax can be added in automatically.
I would say that $200,000 is the tip of a very large iceberg.

Comment: EMTALA does not allow you to get treatment for anything but an emergency medical condition, and the only obligation is to stabilize, not cure or resolve the underlying causes of the emergency. 

It works like this. You show up at the ER with severe shortness of breath caused by your lung cancer. The  ER staff has to screen you for an emergency medical condition and can't delay the screening while asking how you're going to pay. Severe dyspnea is an emergency, so the ER staff would likely treat you with several medications. They may do imaging and admit you if you're still significantly laboring to breath. You might even get a chemo or radiation treatment or two. But, as soon as you are you are stable, the hospital can and likely will discharge you. 

No one has an obligation to further treat you until you are again in severe distress. 

Plus, you remain liable under normal civil law for the cost of your treatment. The hospital can and likely will bill you and pursue collection.
